response_message.content:
Yes ‚Äì you already have an abbreviation for the `fd --extension` (or `fd -e`) option.

In **`fish/load_last_interactive_only/files-search-specific.fish`** you‚Äôll find:

```fish
abbr fd_ext 'fd --extension'
```

So you can type:

```fish
fd_ext py   # expands to: fd --extension py
```

If you prefer an even shorter name you can add your own abbreviation, e.g.:

```fish
abbr fde 'fd --extension'
```

and then use `fde` the same way. After adding it, reload your fish config (`source ~/.config/fish/config.fish` or open a new shell) and the new shortcut will be available.

function.description: Run a process on this darwin machine

argv.description: Executable and arguments. argv[0] is the executable. Required when mode='executable'. Forbidden when mode='shell'.

mode.description: What are you running, two choices: 'shell' or 'executable' (required, no default)

dry_run.description: Optional explain what would run, defaults to False.

timeout_ms.description: Optional timeout in milliseconds, defaults to 1000 milliseconds.

input.description: Optional text written to STDIN (written fully, then closed). Useful for heredoc-style input or file contents.

command_line.description: Shell command line. Required when mode='shell'. Forbidden when mode='executable'.

function.name: run_process

patch.description: file changes in custom diff format

function.name: semantic_grep
function.description: Retrieval tool (the R in RAG) for code and documents in the current workspace. Uses a vector store with embeddings of the entire codebase. And a re-ranker for sorting results.

embed_top_k.description: number of embeddings to consider for reranking

filetype.description: limit matches to a vim compatible filetype. Leave unset for all indexed filetypes in a workspace.

top_k.description: number of results to return (post reranking)

query.description: query text, what you are looking for

messages.content:
You're available via a neovim plugin that displays a chat window (buffer) that renders markdown for answering questions and helping with workspace files in a git repo.

## Ground rules when writing code:

- Follow the user's instructions carefully.
- Do not explain answers using code comments.
- NEVER change **unrelated code and comments.**
- Never add new comments to the end of a line.
- Never add trivial comments.
- Respect indentation when modifying code.
- Prefer readable code over of comments.
- Prefer meaningful names for variables, functions, etc. Avoid ambiguous names.

## Tool use

For tool use, never modify files outside of the current working directory unless the user requested it:
~/repos/github/g0t4/dotfiles

## Use `semantic_grep` to find code

The semantic_grep tool:

- has access to an index of embeddings for the entire codebase
- enables code search, representing the ‚ÄúR‚Äù in RAG (retrieval)
- includes re-ranker
- it's really fast... so don't hesitate to use it!
- while embeddings are great for finding relevant code, if you need to find every occurrence of text, make sure to double-check with a command like `rg`


## Committing

- This project is in a git repo.
- Once a request is complete and verified done, please commit the changes.
- Keep the description concise.
- And, include "Co-Authored-By: gptoss120b" in commit message
- Only commit files you changed.


## Commands

Here are noteworthy commands you have access to:

- fd, rg, gsed, gawk, jq, yq, httpie
- exa, icdiff, ffmpeg, imagemagick, fzf

Here are some *suggestions* too...

### Use `fd` to list files

```sh
# Usage: fd [OPTIONS] [regex] [path]...
fd                      # list files and dirs (except hidden and ignored)
fd foo                  # basename contains "foo" (regex)
fd '^foo' src           # limit to "src" directory (path)
fd --extension js
fd -p foo               # --full-path contains foo
fd --type file
fd --type dir

fd -l                   # think: ls -l
fd --exec stat          # execute stat on each result

fd --hidden             # show hidden files == start with dot like .bashrc
fd --no-ignore          # disable using .gitignore, .ignore, .fdignore to hide files
fd --unrestricted    # show everything: both hidden and ignored

fd --exclude node_modules # glob exclusion (not regex)

fd --max-depth 3
fd --size +10M
fd --changed-within 2hours
fd --changed-before 7days

# Files are versioned in git, so you can use `git` to find files too:
git ls-files

# other commands are fine too! as long as they're not needlessly slow / verbose!
```

### Use `rg` (ripgrep) to search file contents

```sh
rg bar # instead of grep -R
rg -o bar  # only matched part (grep -o)
rg -v bar # invert match (grep -v)
rg --glob="*manual*" embed  # glob filters paths (contains manual)
rg --glob="!*manual*" embed  # ! excludes (does not contain manual)
rg --max-depth 1
rg --multiline
rg --files  # list searched files

fd | rg foo # search STDIN
```

### _Verboten_ Commands

> [!WARNING]
> NEVER use `ls -R` to search for files.
> NEVER use `grep -R` to search file contents.
> NEVER use `find . -type f` to find files, it doesn't give a fuck about ignores, so it will hooover up every node_modules and .venv and take two hours for you to ingest


Other costly mistakes to avoid:

```sh
ls -R ~ # gonna be a late night ü•±
ls -R / # only assholes do this üòà
```

- Never prefer commands that are slow üê¢
- Never run commands that generate butt loads of output, for no good reason... `ls -R` üëÄ

## Use `apply_patch` to edit files.

Your patch language is a stripped‚Äëdown, file‚Äëoriented diff format designed to be easy to parse and safe to apply. You can think of it as a high‚Äëlevel envelope:

*** Begin Patch
[ one or more file sections ]
*** End Patch

Within that envelope, you get a sequence of file operations.
You MUST include a header to specify the action you are taking.
Each operation starts with one of three headers:

*** Add File: <path> - create a new file. Every following line is a + line (the initial contents).
*** Delete File: <path> - remove an existing file. Nothing follows.
*** Update File: <path> - patch an existing file in place (optionally with a rename).

If you want to rename the file too, immediately follow with:
*** Move to: <new path>

Then one or more ‚Äúhunks‚Äù, each introduced by @@ (optionally followed by a hunk header).
Within a hunk each line starts with:

- for inserted text,
* for removed text, or
  space ( ) for context.
  At the end of a truncated hunk you can emit *** End of File.

Here is the grammar:

Patch := Begin { FileOp } End
Begin := "*** Begin Patch" NEWLINE
End := "*** End Patch" NEWLINE
FileOp := AddFile | DeleteFile | UpdateFile
AddFile := "*** Add File: " path NEWLINE { "+" line NEWLINE }
DeleteFile := "*** Delete File: " path NEWLINE
UpdateFile := "*** Update File: " path NEWLINE [ MoveTo ] { Hunk }
MoveTo := "*** Move to: " newPath NEWLINE
Hunk := "@@" [ header ] NEWLINE { HunkLine } [ "*** End of File" NEWLINE ]
HunkLine := (" " | "-" | "+") text NEWLINE

A full patch can combine several operations:

*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: hello.txt
+Hello world
*** Update File: src/app.py
*** Move to: src/main.py
@@ def greet():
-print("Hi")
+print("Hello, world!")
*** Delete File: obsolete.txt
*** End Patch

It is important to remember:

- You must include a header with your intended action (Add/Delete/Update)
- You must prefix new lines with `+` even when creating a new file


Tips on a failure:

- You only need enough context for a unique match!
- The line(s) you replace are context too; if they‚Äôre unique, no additional context is needed.
- Split bigger patches into smaller patches, i.e. if editing two functions, try each separately!
- Watch out for whitespace differences, i.e. blank lines

Please be curteous:

- NEVER leave comments about removed code, just get rid of it. This code lives in a git repo.
- Check your work! Especially after a failure.

### More Examples

Here's a patch file to change the `win` property's type:

```diff
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: src/gap.py
@@ @dataclass
-class GapContext:
-    win: GapWindow
-    gap_rms: TimeSeries
-    analysis: AudioAnalysisResult
+class GapContext:
+    win: SilenceWindow
+    gap_rms: TimeSeries
+    analysis: AudioAnalysisResult
*** End Patch
```

Which can be simplified to:

```diff
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: src/gap.py
@@
-class GapContext:
-    win: GapWindow
+class GapContext:
+    win: SilenceWindow
*** End Patch
```

Or, this could work if the `win` property is unique:

```diff
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: src/gap.py
@@
-    win: GapWindow
+    win: SilenceWindow
*** End Patch
```

## General Code Preferences

- When rewriting code, leave unrelated code and unrelated comments as is.
- When an if statement has an AMBIGUOUS condition, extract a variable to meaningfully name it, for example:
```lua
local is_blank_line = line:match("^%s*$")
if is_blank_line then
    -- ...
end
```

They are using fish shell. Probably they want to create an abbreviation or check existing. We need to look into their dotfiles repo to see if there's a fish config defining such abbreviation. Let's search.

# *** fd general options

abbr fdu 'fd --unrestricted' # no ignores applied (can layer on excludes to remove things again)

abbr fdfp 'fd --full-path' # default matches on basename only, this matches full path
abbr --set-cursor _fdX --regex 'fd\d+' --function _abbr_expand_fdX
